description: Snow: topics covered include how snow forms; wet vs dry snow; the last ice age; snowflakes and their life cycle, the work of Wilson Beckley, famous for photographing 5,500 different snowflakes through a microscope; Inuit people (Arctic circle) who have 40 words for snow (spoken with translation) and build igloos (see "Nanook"(505446) for excellent footage of igloo building); avalanches - including strategic use of them in WW1, the impact they had on Hannibal's crossing of the Alps, and modern control by explosives; blizzards; glaciers and the effect of ice caps on global climate. "Fog": topics include what conditions create fog, dew and frost; humidity; famous disasters resulting from fog and efforts of prevention (WW2 airstrips, fog horns, fog "seeding"); San Francisco (in fog 85% of year) and the coastal giant Redwoods dependence on these fog conditions; collection of fog as water supply to lower desert areas in the Andes; English "dew artist" Chris Hunter; differences between hoar-frost, fir-frost and rime-frost; frost damage to crops, methods of prevention and environmental consequences of this; smog, including details of the famous 1952 peas souper of London that killed 4,000 people in 5 days and Mexico City which has the worst smog in the modern world. "Signs in the Sky": topics include descriptions of weather phenomena seen in sky, what creates them and how to read weather signs - types of cloud and how they were named; rainbows and fogbows; Brocken Spectre; halos; Silvan shine; mirages (prevented John Ross finding north west passage to Greenland); auroras and eclipses.
